My other tips:
- Start incorporating thrift, consignment & second-hand clothes in your wardrobe (host a clothing swap w/ friends for a no-spend option)
- Walk, bike, & use public transit more often
- Bring your own bag/coffee mug. It‚Äôs okay if you forget, 1x/week is still a win

Rikers Island is in my district.

Due to Census law, people incarcerated at Rikers are counted as my constituents (instead of at their home community).

Changing policy is about changing how we treat people, & we have an obligation to hold our criminal justice system to account. https://t.co/S7WRYZBQ9g

All too often, our criminal justice system - from tickets to convictions - is treated as a game, where the one racks up the most ‚Äúpoints‚Äù wins.

Paired w/ foolish criminalization of marijuana, poverty,etc, it wrecks chaos on people‚Äôs lives + stagnates communities for generations.

As a result, our system is ‚Äúinnocent until proven guilty‚Äù only for the rich &‚Äúguilty until proven innocent‚Äù for the poor.

To borrow from @ZephyrTeachout, the RADICAL rule of law is the idea that in the same scenario, our courts would treat a billionaire the same as a Bronx teen.

It does not mean the treatment + presumption of guilt before a verdict. It does not mean we aim for the most punitive punishment.

It means that in the eyes of the law, we treat everyone the same.

That‚Äôs far from what our current system does. And that‚Äôs why it must change.

One of the biggest ways predatory financial actors get away w/it all is manufactured shame around personal finance.

When working people aren‚Äôt paid a living wage, they become easy prey.

Sure, ‚Äòmobilizing the economy to save our planet from irreparable global catastrophe‚Äô SOUNDS nice, but will it play well in the Midwest? ü§î https://t.co/L9N2KkuYBE

‚ÄúClimate change is not a market glitch to be fixed through pricing... but part of a dire social crisis.‚Äù

The GND Resolution‚Äôs purpose is to *define the scope* of a climate solution.

Now, from investing into battery tech to fixing water pipes, we can draft projects in the plan. https://t.co/q9faiP2dUA

For far too long, ideas like a carbon tax or cap-and-trade were touted as the premier solutions to climate change.

While those things could be *part* of a solution, the GND resolution says they are inadequate as the whole answer.

The pipes in Flint weren‚Äôt a ‚Äúmarket failure.‚Äù

The pipes in Flint weren‚Äôt a market failure, they were a social failure.

It was a failure to see the people in Flint as important as the WH. Those decisions were predicated on a legacy of racism + dehumanization of the poor.

The enviro issue of water is how that was expressed.

And part of what the #GreenNewDeal says, at last, is that Flint wasn‚Äôt an accident.
The folks dying in West Virginia aren‚Äôt an accident.
The Bronx having one of the highest child asthma rates isn‚Äôt an accident.

It‚Äôs a structural failure to care, & treat these communities fairly.

Finally, the reason we scope out with a resolution is bc I am not here to say that only one member of Congress will solve a global crisis.

Think of the GND Res as a ‚ÄúRequest for Proposals.‚Äù

We‚Äôve defined the scope and where we want to go. Now let‚Äôs assess + collab on projects.

Gonna keep it üíØ: The biggest threats to journalism right now are tech monopolies & concentration of ownership.

Healthy democracy *requires* high-quality journalism.

W/o a wide range of independent outlets & the revenue to sustain them, our democracy will continue to crumble.

Most platforms currently have 0 incentive to disseminate high-quality, true information.

In fact, FB *paid* for info tied to conspiracy theories on those demanding for accountability.

It matters. Soros was the 1st to get mailed a bomb last year.

https://t.co/zaf6NpmKPm

The fact of the matter is the current monopoly trend is societally & economically unsustainable.

We can‚Äôt simply accept the clich√© that ‚Äújournalism is dying.‚Äù

Journalism will only die if we choose not to fight for it - and if journalism dies, our democracy will, too.

If you want to read more on the issue of monopolies, anti-trust, corruption, and ways to address it, I recommend checking out @ZephyrTeachout. 

She literally wrote the book on it.

I want to be very clear about how successful the work of grassroots organizers and activists have been in helping Progressives secure appointments to the powerful Financial Services Committee.

It starts, as w/ many amazing developments, w/ everyday people paying attention. https://t.co/oKBI0OXCAz

During + after the 2008 financial crisis, everyday people started to viscerally see the corrosive role of lobbyists writing in legal loopholes that allowed big banks to gamble with people‚Äôs lives and the economy as a whole.

Occupy Wall Street emerged, and activism bloomed.

Activists zoomed in on one place in particular: the Financial Services Committee, which deals with big banks, real estate, and almost every interaction people have in dealing with their own money.

What they found was a place where big bank lobbyists were slipping in their work.

Fin Services is one of few exclusive committees.

The jargon around here is that they are the ‚Äúmoney committees,‚Äù not bc they oversee money,but bc one can fundraise from special interests by sitting on it and giving corporations a listening ear.

Until people started paying attn.

All of a sudden, normal people whose student loans were bubbling, whose mortgages were underwater, and so on, started showing up to committee hearings.

Including this guy: Monopoly Man

The idea was to show legislators that everyday people were watching.
https://t.co/YU4Bw8P1Sg

All of a sudden, it became harder for legislators to slip corporate-friendly legislation through committee, because people would write articles and their constituents would find out and grow upset.

As I‚Äôve said before, it‚Äôs People vs Money. We‚Äôve got people, they‚Äôve got money.

These legislators, under public pressure, couldn‚Äôt deliver as much for big bank lobbyists.

They had to vacate one of the most powerful committees in the House. That made a space that big banks couldn‚Äôt fill, and how we got *several* non-Corp funded members into places of power.

I cannot stress how important this moment is.

Dems are putting members who rejected corporate campaign money on a committee overseeing Wall St.

All because: 
1. Everyday people donated to our campaigns, and
2. They started to pay attention + became activists in Congress

It‚Äôs a huge win. Obviously there is work to do - there are other money committees (Ways & Means, Energy & Commerce, etc). But we‚Äôve got one down. Before we had 0.

Keep paying attention, chipping into campaigns, and being activists. It works.

The most humbling gifts of this experience: the handful of letters I have received from people who knew my father.

For those who don‚Äôt know, I lost my dad at a young age. In many ways, it triggered a series of events that put me here.

Through strangers, I am learning about him.

I received a letter yesterday from a long-lost friend of his, who shared an apartment building and childhood with him in the South Bronx.

I learned his favorite superhero and baseball player; that he once tried to make a home-made parachute to fly off a fire escape as a kid.

I adored my father. Losing him was very hard for my family, and I fight because I know how many families out there experience similar pains.

Ultimately, I‚Äôm a kid looking at her backyard, and doing her part to make the crooked path straight.

In a way, I think we all are.

Almost two years ago, I started what was then a completely ‚Äòimpossible‚Äô bid for Congress.

Since then, everything has changed.

Now, there‚Äôs only 20 minutes left.

And it feels great.

I have spent today criss-crossing the district my family has called home for generations. I have met strangers who knew my dad, and knew stories about my loved ones.

I have touched the hands of people who have felt ignored and invisible for a long, long time. And they felt seen.

Today I saw people voting that are almost never seen in an off-year midterm primary.

Just now, as I‚Äôm typing this with 8 minutes left, two young men of color, 20 years old, just walked up to me and said they just voted.

2 yrs ago, the ‚Äúexperts‚Äù told me not to bother with them.

But I knew that in refusing to engage with non-voters, we were churning a cycle of neglect and cynicism.

So I reached out. And we have been embraced. We have built power. We have organized.

What we have built is permanent. No. Matter. What.

We triggered the first primary election in 14 years. OUR supporters, collecting signatures in the bitter snow for 5 weeks, did that.

No matter who the vote is for, every single vote cast to day is ours - because we made this election happen.

This is the start of a movement.

Thank you all.

Oh man, this Skillman Bike lane issue is HEATED. I went to the town hall for it and it was packed to the max.

I‚Äôve sat with activists and small business owners on this issue.

Here are my initial thoughts - this issue is STRONGLY connected to role of real estate devs in NYC. /1 https://t.co/A2jpezayzQ

I think a bike lane is a good idea. We‚Äôve had far too many tragedies in the area (@MakeQueensSafer has been doing good work here too).

People have intense, daily frustration w/ far less access to parking than they had before. But we also need to address WHY this is happening. /2

Basically, real estate developers are buying off rezonings from elected officials via campaign finance.

This causes new buildings to bring in 100s/1000s more people into a neighborhood without making *any* public investments.

Schools, sewage, & yes, parking all get strained. /3

Because these developers don‚Äôt seem to support expanded municipal parking (like some of the ones found in Astoria), it causes the community to fight over scraps.

We can make moves that increase local parking while still having safe bike lanes. /4

Some of the ideas/issues I‚Äôve heard from local Woodside+Sunnyside residents:

- Residential parking on side streets
- Uber drivers from BK & outer Queens are leaving their cars in Woodside for days/week+ at a time. They don‚Äôt live there + take spaces from locals
- Municipal lots!

@macartney @MakeQueensSafer Yes, apologies if that was unclear - the bike lanes have a very clear + serious why. 

I had meant addressing why local drivers are so worked up over it. At the core, I think they want a safe neighborhood too - we can increase parking elsewhere to accommodate for the bike lane.
@macartney @MakeQueensSafer I‚Äôd love that!
@_paul_pablo_ @macartney I do! üíú

1080 parking spots! Demolished w/o replacement! This is what I‚Äôm talking about.

Real estate devs don‚Äôt like garages because they can make more $ otherwise. But if they bring people in, they should realize we need to accommodate them with more schools, sewage plants, and PARKING. https://t.co/JxpUQXX75p

This isn‚Äôt even going into the fact that the city stopped planning for new public infrastructure decades ago.

We also need to plan for big ideas like more outer-borough public transit (Bronx to Queens, anyone?) to reduce the number of cars we need in the first place.

@acharya_dude I‚Äôm definitely open to hearing this side of this issue - all in all NYC works better with less cars on the road. I try to think of this from a ‚Äúshort-term needs to long-term goals‚Äù perspective.

About 10 years ago I worked in Ted Kennedy‚Äôs foreign affairs/immigration constituent office.

I REGULARLY fielded calls from panicked mothers who came home to missing family members.

ICE was created in 2003 along w/ the Patriot Act. It was a weapon waiting for a tyrant.

/1

Folks are also talking about how this isn‚Äôt just Trump.

That is true, and not new to folks familiar with US immigration. Obama deported more people than his three presidential predecessors *combined.*

But now we are seeing exactly how ICE was designed without accountability. /2

Like warrantless wiretapping, the extrajudicial and unaccountable nature of ICE is essentially built as a maiden in waiting for authoritarian abuse of power.

In fact, the folks who panic about the idea of #abolishICE seem to forget that we had a system before it: the INS.

/3

The INS forwarded crimes to the Department of Justice.

That is exactly how it should be done.

Immigration should primarily be seen through two lenses (arguably 1-2 others):

1. Foreign policy
2. Criminal justice

/4

1. Immigration as foreign policy

Families do not all come to the US because they spontaneously ‚Äúfeel like it.‚Äù They also come because of global trade deals that destabilize local economies, or military interventionism, or regime changes at home.

/5

Whenever we as US citizens agree w/ military actions like weapons deals & air strikes, or when we hop on board with trade deals like NAFTA or the TPP, we should ask ourselves:

‚ÄúAre we prepared to deal with the people who will seek refuge in the US due to our actions?‚Äù

/6

2. Immigration as Criminal Justice

If a person commits a crime, they should go through due process as outlined in our Constitution. Period.

That‚Äôs how it was until 2003. ICE changed all of that, and created an extrajudicial black-box system that has deported >10k US citizens(!)

Here‚Äôs what must be done:

We must #abolishICE. It‚Äôs very structure is about as undemocratic and authoritarian as it gets in the US.

We have to replace ICE with an updated INS-like structure that handles crime through the same court system we‚Äôve had for well over 100 years. /8

In NY to be in the Democratic primary, you must collect 1,250 VALID signatures.

A valid sig is one of a registered Democrat that resides within the district lines of NY-14, and is registered to vote there. The signature must be WITNESSED by another registered Dem in NY. /4

If the witness is not a Dem, then the Dem‚Äôs signature is thrown out.

If the Dem‚Äôs sig doesn‚Äôt match their voter reg, it‚Äôs also thrown out. The ‚Äúmatch‚Äù is determined by a judge.

But what if one candidate appointed the judges for challengers?

Welcome to the Queens machine! /5

Economics 101 reminder: The stock market is NOT the economy.

Stocks aren‚Äôt jobs. Stocks aren‚Äôt wages.

That‚Äôs why stock prices can go up and normal people still won‚Äôt feel any more secure about their future.

Recessions are when real GDP growth falls for 2 quarters in a row.

You can‚Äôt tell much from one day of stock trading.

However, many Wall Street CEOs are compensated by stock price performance. That encourages behavior like stock buy-backs to inflate prices (and consequently, CEO pay) instead of investing in wages, R&D, or training workers.
There‚Äôs a good case study on how this works: https://t.co/ZBPVQbpmWx

This is not to speak to larger trends. Economists and traders alike know that it‚Äôs impossible to time the market.

Our current economic system guarantees busts and booms.

We as voters must decide what kind of society we want in the bust: one with a safety net, or not?

Martin Luther King knew that economic and racial issues weren‚Äôt either/or; that race and class were wedded together in the foundations of American history.

MLK‚Äôs writings echo in today‚Äôs debate on ‚Äúidentity‚Äù issues vs ‚Äúeconomic‚Äù issues (among others). MLK knew this was a false choice: that no matter what, working class Americans are in this together.

If you do anything to mark MLK day, I ask that you listen not to King's seminal "I Have a Dream" speech, but his final one: "I Have Been to the Mountaintop."

3min excerpt: https://t.co/nPu6jaEYtz

Full speech (listen on your commute or as a podcast): https://t.co/EB63g5NndC https://t.co/tDHelDlX5x

"Somewhere I read of the freedom of assembly.
Somewhere I read of the freedom of speech.
Somewhere I read of the freedom of press.

Somewhere I read that the greatness of America is the right to protest for right."

-MLK, The Mountaintop

King was organizing for LABOR rights - more specifically, demanding dignified pay and safer working conditions for the sanitation workers of Memphis, Tennessee.

He was assassinated the day after delivering this speech.
@baratunde Thank you! I‚Äôll incorporate it.

Let‚Äôs look at MLK‚Äôs writing.

Many people have heard of MLK‚Äôs Letter from a Birmingham Jail, but what some don‚Äôt know is that this letter is a chapter in his larger book, Why We Can‚Äôt Wait.

Here he outlines the urgency of protest and social change.

Here‚Äôs my tattered copy. https://t.co/i7PxlIJe2A

Chapters in Why We Can‚Äôt Wait include:

- The Negro Revolution- Why 1963?
- The Sword That Heals
- Letter from Birmingham Jail
- Black and White Together
- The Summer of our Discontent
- The Days to Come

Fun Fact: MLK mentions the plight of Puerto Ricans in the introduction üáµüá∑

MLK outlined four steps of a nonviolent campaign:

1. Collection of facts to determine the existence of injustice;
2. Negotiation
3. Self-Purification
4. Direct Action

Notice how much work and preparation went in before a single protest (aka direct action).

I want to talk a little bit about MLK‚Äôs step of self-purification here.

For MLK, this step included workshops preparing people to ‚Äúaccept blows without retaliating‚Äù and psychologically ‚Äúenduring the ordeal of jail.‚Äù

Nonviolent direct action is a spiritual struggle that continues today.

Just ask any of Lakota Sioux elders at Standing Rock. One of the first principles communicated to me there was ‚Äúeverything you do here is ceremony.‚Äù

It takes deep personal commitment to pursue social change.
@Doc_Zuckerbrot Thank you for your support!

Protestors with MLK pledged to keep the following 10 commandments to spiritually prepare for action:

1. MEDITATE on teachings and life of Jesus. (MLK was a pastor)

2. REMEMBER to seek justice, not victory.

3. WALK and talk in the manner of love, for God is Love. 

cont... /1 https://t.co/jfxkDS3qzx

4. PRAY to be used by God so that all men might be free.

5. SACRIFICE personal wishes so that all men might be free.

6. OBSERVE with friend AND foe the ordinary rules of courtesy.

7. SEEK to perform regular service for others and the world.

...

8. REFRAIN from the violence of fist, tongue, or heart.

9. STRIVE to be in good spiritual and bodily health.

10. FOLLOW the directions of the movement and the captain of the demonstration.

These rules are all applicable today as we look to actors of nonviolent resistance across the country and globe.

MLK and the struggle for civil rights lives today at Standing Rock, Ferguson, Women's March, Stonewall. He gifted the nation a blueprint for change.

Rounding out today's MLK teach-in, let's talk about the end.

After the civil rights movement, he famously said: ‚ÄúI fear I may have integrated my people into a burning house."

His work evolved into a full-throated fight for economic justice: universal healthcare, higher wages...

...and ending the Vietnam war.

MLK knew that fanning the flames of racism was a tool used by the powerful to sabotage the organization of working class Americans.

But the solution wasn't, and isn't, to ignore issues of racial injustice. It is coming together and heal the wound.

MLK knew his life was in danger and that he would likely lead a short life. He directly addresses that in his Mountaintop speech on the day before his death.

By then his family home had been bombed and the FBI sent him blackmail encouraging his suicide. (https://t.co/pWc9x8JImR)

I bring up the FBI letter not to be controversial, but to plainly acknowledge the true danger that activists face in advancing causes of justice.

MLK's phones was wiretapped and lived under constant gov surveillance. A fed judge sealed the audio of MLK's wiretaps until the 2027.

Like many activists today, MLK was investigated, threatened, called a fraud, and subject to smear campaigns - by both citizens and government alike. We should recall this when we see activists working in America today.

Rose-colored interpretations of MLK hurt progress, because they reinforce a false notion that we must be perfect messengers to advocate. MLK was not perfect - far from it. And we don't have to be perfect, either - we just have to be brave.
